# Wav2Vec2Phoneme

[Wav2Vec2Phoneme](https://huggingface.co/papers/2109.11680) is a specialized version of Wav2Vec2 designed for zero-shot cross-lingual phoneme recognition. It's like having a universal speech decoder that can understand the building blocks of speech across different languages, even ones it hasn't seen before. By mapping phonemes using articulatory features, it can transcribe unseen languages with remarkable accuracy.

You can find all the original [Wav2Vec2Phoneme](https://huggingface.co/models?other=phoneme-recognition) checkpoints on the Hugging Face Hub.

> [!TIP]
> Click on the Wav2Vec2Phoneme models in the right sidebar for more examples of how to apply Wav2Vec2Phoneme to different phoneme recognition tasks.

The example below demonstrates how to perform phoneme recognition using the [`Pipeline`] or the [`AutoModel`] class.

<hfoptions id="usage">
<hfoption id="Pipeline">

```python
from transformers import pipeline

# Phoneme Recognition
phoneme_recognizer = pipeline("automatic-speech-recognition", model="facebook/wav2vec2-phoneme")
phonemes = phoneme_recognizer("path/to/audio.wav")

# The output will be a sequence of phonemes
print(phonemes)
```

</hfoption>
<hfoption id="AutoModel">

```python
from transformers import AutoProcessor, Wav2Vec2ForCTC
import torch

# Load model and processor
processor = AutoProcessor.from_pretrained("facebook/wav2vec2-phoneme")
model = Wav2Vec2ForCTC.from_pretrained("facebook/wav2vec2-phoneme")

# Prepare audio input (assuming you have audio data)
audio_input = load_audio("path/to/audio.wav")
inputs = processor(audio_input, sampling_rate=16000, return_tensors="pt", padding=True)

Generate logits
with torch.no_grad():
    logits = model(**inputs).logits

Decode to phonemes
predicted_ids = torch.argmax(logits, dim=-1)
phonemes = processor.batch_decode(predicted_ids)
```

</hfoption>
</hfoptions>

Quantization reduces the memory burden of large models by representing the weights in a lower precision. Refer to the [Quantization](../quantization/overview) overview for more available quantization backends.

The example below uses [bitsandbytes quantization](https://huggingface.co/docs/transformers/main/en/main_classes/quantization) to quantize the weights to 8-bit:

```python
from transformers import Wav2Vec2ForCTC
import torch

model = Wav2Vec2ForCTC.from_pretrained(
    "facebook/wav2vec2-phoneme",
    load_in_8bit=True,
    device_map="auto"
)
```

## Notes

### Model Architecture
Wav2Vec2Phoneme uses the exact same architecture as Wav2Vec2, making it fully compatible with existing Wav2Vec2 workflows and pipelines.

### Phoneme Recognition
- The model outputs a sequence of phonemes by default
- Uses connectionist temporal classification (CTC) for training
- Requires [`Wav2Vec2PhonemeCTCTokenizer`] for decoding
- Can be fine-tuned on multiple languages simultaneously

### Cross-Lingual Capabilities
- Maps phonemes of training languages to target languages using articulatory features
- Enables zero-shot cross-lingual transfer learning
- Can decode unseen languages in a single forward pass
- Significantly outperforms previous zero-shot methods

### Post-Processing
To transform phonemes to words, you'll need:
- A dictionary mapping phonemes to words
- A language model for sequence refinement

### Performance
This simple method significantly outperforms prior work that introduced task-specific architectures and used only part of a monolingually pretrained model.

### API Reference
Wav2Vec2Phoneme's architecture is based on the Wav2Vec2 model. For API reference, check out [`Wav2Vec2`](wav2vec2)'s documentation page except for the tokenizer.

---

## API Reference

### Wav2Vec2PhonemeCTCTokenizer

[[autodoc]] Wav2Vec2PhonemeCTCTokenizer
	- __call__
	- batch_decode
	- decode
	- phonemize
